description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: Data should relate to all sites in the UK. This includes England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
We will treat your information securely and confidentially.

This survey is refreshed every two weeks. To avoid losing data and to help us provide real-time information please submit by the return by date, or at the latest before the next fortnightly survey goes live.
On average it takes five minutes to complete this survey once you have collected the information.
You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ’Download as PDF’ button.

contents.description: Please complete this survey even if you are a sole trader and it does not seem relevant to your business. All returns are important, as it allows decision-makers to understand how businesses of all sizes are performing in the current climate.
Thank you for participating in this important survey.
View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey has the following sections:
This section asks for general information on your business’s trading status.
This section asks for information about:

list: factors impacting your business’s supply chains
increasing supply chain resilience

contents.description: This section asks for information about the current actions taken by your business to protect the environment, reduce carbon emissions and respond to climate change.
We are asking this to understand how the UK Government’s target of net zero carbon emissions may be affecting business’s actions in relation to climate change.
This section asks for information about your business’s use of artificial intelligence technologies.
This section asks for information about:

list: expectations for cash reserves
insolvency
debt obligations

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business’s use of Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) process.

The data from this survey is used widely to enable rapid response, and inform policy decisions about issues impacting UK businesses and the economy. This includes topics relating to business resilience, financial performance, trade and your workforce.

title.text: Which of the following factors, if any, is {ru_name} concerned about impacting supply chains over the next 12 months?

options.label: Increased barriers to trade
options.description: This refers to barriers that make it more difficult for businesses to source the inputs they are seeking from a given market. These can include tariff increases and new regulations

options.label: Market distorting practices
options.description: This refers to practices that may undermine free and fair trade and prevent businesses from competing based on merit

options.label: Shipping disruption
options.description: For example, the Red Sea crisis

options.label: Business is not concerned about factors impacting supply chains over the next 12 months

question.title: How does your business expect these factors to impact supply chains?

options.label: Shortage of inputs
options.description: This refers to any resources used to create goods and services. These include intermediate goods used in production, labour, fuel, and equipment

options.label: Business does not expect these factors to impact supply chains

question.title: Which of the following actions, if any, did your business take to increase supply chain resilience in the last 12 months?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’increase supply chain resilience’

contents.description: This refers to the ability of the business to respond to disruptions and reduces the likelihood and scale of any future disruptions.

options.label: Demand management
options.description: For example, identifying whether it is beneficial to manage the demand for components or goods, considering substitutes and alternatives, innovation, and circularity

options.label: Diversification of suppliers across a broader range of countries
Increased awareness of supply chains
options.description: For example, greater data gathering and sharing

options.label: Onshoring
options.description: This refers to sourcing inputs from the company’s original country

options.label: Relocated existing sourcing to another country

definitions.title: What we mean by ’artificial intelligence technologies’

contents.description: This refers to computer programs or machines that can learn from data and perform tasks usually done by humans.

options.label: Data processing using machine learning
options.description: For example, personalisation of shopping or product recommendations, fraud prevention or cybersecurity

options.label: Image processing using machine learning
options.description: For example, for facial recognition, quality control or object detection

options.label: Robotics
options.description: For example, for carrying goods in hospitals or warehouses

options.label: Text generation using Large Language Models
options.description: For example, chatbots that interact in a conversational way and can answer complex questions, computer coding assistance, creating first drafts of papers or topic research or social media posts and public communications

options.label: Visual content creation
options.description: For example, for use in graphic design or videos

options.label: Business does not currently use artificial intelligence technologies

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business’s use of Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) process.

title.text: Has {ru_name} gone through the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) process in the last five years?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment)’

contents.description: This refers to regulations which may protect employees when a business changes ownership and is sometimes referred to as TUPE. There are two types of transfer protected under TUPE:

list: business transfers, where a business or part of a business moves from one employer to another
service provision changes, when a service is transferred to a new provider
